title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – On a night where the scoreboard told only half the story, the Houston Rockets rode the broad shoulders of Hakeem Olajuwon to a gritty victory over the Los Angeles Lakers. In a classic 1997 battle, the Rockets outlasted their rivals 100-96, but the final score was merely a footnote to the historic, singular performance of "The Dream."

Hakeem Olajuwon was not merely the best player on the floor; he was a force of nature, authoring a performance for the ages. He erupted for a game-high 46 points, a staggering number that dwarfed all other scorers. But his dominance didn't stop there. He was an immovable object on the glass, hauling in 22 rebounds to complete a superhuman double-double that left the Lakers searching for answers.

Los Angeles, led by Shaquille O'Neal's 26 points and 19 rebounds, fought valiantly. But on this night, Shaq was not the dominant big man; he was a witness. The Lakers' balance, with Eddie Jones adding 20 points, was simply no match for the Olajuwon hurricane that swept through the Summit.

The game was a tense, back-and-forth affair, but in the final, decisive moments, there was no mystery. Every crucial possession ran through Olajuwon. He was the offense, the defense, and the heart of the Rockets. Clyde Drexler's 17 points provided vital support, but this was Hakeem's masterpiece.

When the final buzzer sounded, the 100-96 result secured the win for Houston. But the true story was the stat sheet, where one line—46 points, 22 rebounds—stood as a monument to one man's will and a timeless reminder of Hakeem Olajuwon's legendary greatness.
